content.description: Offwidth crack with a thin hands crack at the very back. crux is exiting the top of the crack, great for eliminates
content.protection: gear to 1.5", good pro in the walls of the offwidth, no need for big gear.
content.location: East wall of the amphitheater, below the southern bolted anchors

content.description: From Tim Olson book "This classic line (and the next one) are the central feature of the West Nook.  they offer complexity, steepness, and quality great for bouldering or for a top-rope.
content.location: Route is immediately left of the Flake route, in West Nook of First Ampitheater.

content.description:
Tricky start, trends leftward as get into the second half, including time for a super positive mono (1 finger hold).

Here's what the Olson book says: "A stellar V2 thin crack corner that is much harder than it looks. Using rules staying in the crack will make it a V3.   Traversing in from the far left then up the central corner crack is V4.
content.location: Immediately left of the route called Crack Seam in West Nook  of First Ampitheater.  Also this is #21 in Tim Olson NW Oregon Rock book.

content.description: Extraordinarily exposed boulder problem. Sit start the arete on the right. The moves are awkward.
content.location: Situated on a ledge near the "summit" of HTB. The ledge is ~8' wide, and maybe 100' off the deck. A fall is NOT safe. In the event of a fall, try no to roll off the edge.

content.description: Start on the left line, and higher right hold. Climb up to the jutting feature, and ascend to a decent top out with an excellent shelf on the right.
content.protection: A few crash pads and a spotter
content.location: Directly across from the established routes mentioned in the bouldering guide book. Use the route "Arrowhead" as a beacon.

content.description: Start on the obvious chalked, jutting, left hold, and right side pull. Climb up the nose of the boulder with small, crimpy holds on each side. Navigate passed the tricky sloper-pinch, gripping anything decent you can find, then launch to a decent hold and proceed carefully to the top. *EDIT* June, 2018, A newly released guidebook features this route as a V4 named "Tall Arete"
content.protection: At least 3 crash pads and a spotter, more would be better.
content.location: Directly across the trail from the bouldering spot mentioned in the guide book. Use the established route "Arrowhead" as a beacon.

content.description: SDS with undercling and sidepull on an arete, bad feet. Shoot up and left to a tiny dimple (this is the singular "hard" move), walk up the feet (optional), and finish with jugs of your choosing.
content.location: In a small depression on the top of the butte. South side.

climbs.name: I dynno if I should try this.

content.description:
Tiny foot chip start crank hard off and dyno to the jug above it.

I am 6'0'' with +1.5 span and I can just almost deadpoint the move.

Very fun move and easy top out once you have made the dyno...especially for it being on a slab wall.
content.location:
Walk in from the left fork of the trail. Once inside the bouldering area take the opening to the right (about 50 yards after entering the rock area) follow that until you see the signs for no climbing area, the rock is passed that 50 ft on the left, has some warm up v0-v3 on it and on the back side of it is the slab wall.

On the same wall as daniel on bouldery crack picture, but to the right.

content.description: Hug your way up the nose of the boulder.
content.location: Right next to Spot You to Death, or directly across the trail from the established wall mentioned in the bouldering guidebook. Use "Arrowhead" as a beacon

content.description: Sit start to an amazing flake that trends leftwards, then jugs to the top.
content.location: #19 in Tim Olson NW Oregon Rock book.  When you enter the first ampitheater, you'll see a "no climbing" sign on the right.  This climb is in the nook 10 ft ACROSS from the no climbing sign (not the same face as the no climbing sign of course).

content.description: Right side of the arete, the obvious inner corner. Climb up easy rock to a stance at an incut and a long reach to a decent hold. Find some creative body positions to stem out and around the seamed-out crack, reach the good hold, and work your feet up until you can reach jugs. Very easy last few moves. Lots of good cracks to belay from in the .5-1" range. Easy walk-off.

Around the left side of the arete. Climb cracks and steps to a ledge. From this there are three options: finger crack, OW, and hand crack. Take the right option up the short but sweet fissure savoring the mild exposure on the arete. Clutch the edge at the top and scramble to the top. Lots of good cracks to belay from in the .5-1" range. Easy walk-off.

Around the left side of the arete. Climb cracks and steps to a ledge. Follow the obvious finger crack straight up with a crux at the top gaining the very questionable flake. Lots of good cracks to belay from in the .5-1" range. Easy walk-off.
